Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Opportunities in Bioinspired Robotics

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site program at the University of Maryland (UMD)College Park offers new and exciting summer research opportunities to diverse and talented cohorts of undergraduates, from institutions with limited or no research opportunities in the field of bioinspired robotics (defined as robots that are inspired by natural systems such as insects, birds, mammals, and reptiles). Bioinspired robots will be used to target the efforts of first responders after a natural disaster and provide a number of tasks to assist humans (e.g., carrying extra goods, repairing damaged goods, building structures, etc.). However, designing, fabricating, and applying these robots is a long-term scientific and engineering challenge. Each summer, this REU site will provide 10 undergraduates with resources and opportunities to begin tackling some of these challenges. The program will collaborate with UMD's Women in Engineering program and the Center for Minorities in Science and Engineering to better recruit and assess the impact of this program on women and underrepresented minority students who traditionally suffer from the "leaky pipeline" in which percentages of these students decrease as they move up through the ranks of research positions. This problem will be addressed by focusing on career and academic development (seminars and graduate student mentors) in addition to providing a new network of role models through a diverse mentoring pool. A more diverse group of highly educated researchers in this critical research field will create a larger workforce to solve the nation's toughest environmental, technical, and national security challenges.

Bioinspired robotics offer a truly interdisciplinary systems research challenge that encompasses biology, materials, mechanical design, control, sensors and actuators, power, and electronics. To provide the collaborations necessary to solve some of these challenges and encourage students toward future research careers, the program will: 1. Define diverse teams of faculty, graduate student mentors, and undergraduate researchers. 2. Provide exciting research topics covering many aspects of bioinspired robotics. 3. Encourage collaboration and discussion through non-traditional means, including social media forums like Facebook and informal lunch talks among students. 4. Offer tutorial and professional development seminars in addition to field trips to local labs. 5. Assess project success through short-term, long-term, quantitative and qualitative metrics. The discoveries made during these collaborations will be communicated to the broader scientific community via publications and presentations.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this REU experience was to offer new and exciting summer research opportunities for undergraduate students in the field of bioinspired robotics.  Bioinspired robots, defined as robots that are inspired by natural systems such as insects, birds, mammals, and reptiles, have the potential to significantly enable or enhance capabilities in manufacturing, health care, reconnaissance, exploration, food safety, and search and rescue.  Because of their unique design, bioinspired robotics offer a truly interdisciplinary systems research challenge that encompasses biology, materials, mechanical design, control, sensors and actuators, power, and electronics. This REU experience was able to take advantage of The Maryland Robotics Center and the Institute for Systems Research at the University of Maryland (UMD), both of which have expertise and facilities needed to support research opportunities to undergraduates in bioinspired robotics. The program had its first cohort in Summer 2017, a second cohort in Summer 2018, and the last cohort in Summer 2019.

 

The goals of the Bioinspired Robotics REU site are:

 

  • Teach students about bioinspired robotics and the applicable technologies and applications
  • Engage talented and diverse students in interdisciplinary research programs
  • Increase the number of underrepresented students in future research careers
  • Prepare students for graduate school or research jobs in industry and labs
  • Introduce undergraduates to team-based interdisciplinary research
  • Build a strong community between undergraduates, graduate student mentors, and faculty

 

Each year, 10 students were selected for a cohort to participate in the program. There were a diverse array of applicants, and over 140 students applied each year. This indicated the program was very popular with students, but also made the selection process very challenging, since nearly all of the applicants were outstanding. It also meant that it was possible to select a diverse cohort each year.

All 30 participants in this project were assigned to a faculty advisor for their research experience. A diverse and multidisciplinary group of advisors were involved, including 4 male faculty and 3 female faculty from Mechanical Engineering, Electrical & Computer Engineering, and Aerospace Engineering. One of the primary objectives of this REU site is to provide an opportunity for training, development and mentoring and all of the research and education activities described above are directed toward this goal. Each accepted undergraduate student is assigned both a faculty mentor and a graduate student mentor as part of the program. In addition, they often have additional mentors (graduate student or senior undergraduate student) in their lab to go to for help on technical questions with their research covering multiple facets of bioinspired robotics. These included:

  • Bioinspired robotics in space
  • Insect inspired microrobots
  • Bioinspired robot birds
  • Navigation for bioinspired robotics
  • Dynamics and controls of soft robots on land and in water
  • Actuators for bioinspired robots
  • Bioinspired sensors for robotics

Tutorials on bioinspired robotics and their related fields, workshops on professional development, lab tours, and field trips complemented these research opportunities.

Our impact in robotics and bioinspired engineering has primarily been in the form of human resources through the training of students in area of bioinspired robotics. The use of tutorial talks in particular expose the student participants to many areas of robotics and bioinspired engineering that they would not otherwise learn about. However, the students also make impacts on their own as well through the final reports in IEEE conference paper format they prepare at the end of their program, which are often converted into conference or journal papers. We have also continued to improve the pedagogy of our own program through topics and program coordination (matching students with mentors, etc.). We will not have a good view of our longterm results for another several years, but we hope that more students exposed to robotics and bioinspired engineering will create more of an affect on these two important disciplines.

We use several of our REU projects as demos for Maryland Day, attended by 75,000 people, as well as community educational outreach at local schools and libraries. It is particularly inspiring when people learn  that the projects were accomplished by undergraduate students.
